{{TennisEventInfo|2010|Morocco Tennis Tour – Rabat| | date=March 8 – March 14 | edition=5th | location=[[Rabat]], [[Morocco]] | champs={{flagicon|ESP}} [[Rubén Ramírez Hidalgo]] | champd={{flagicon|SRB}} [[Ilija Bozoljac]] / {{flagicon|ITA}} [[Daniele Bracciali]] }}
The '''2010 [[Morocco Tennis Tour – Rabat]]''' was a professional [[tennis]] tournament played on [[Tennis court#Clay courts|outdoor red clay courts]]. It was part of the [[2010 ATP Challenger Tour]]. It took place in [[Rabat]], [[Morocco]] between 9 and 15 March 2010.
==ATP entrants==
===Seeds=== {| class="wikitable" border="1" |- ! Nationality ! Player ! Ranking* ! Seeding |- | {{flag|UKR}} | [[Oleksandr Dolgopolov Jr.]] | 81 | 1 |- | {{flag|ESP}} | [[Santiago Ventura Bertomeu|Santiago Ventura]] | 90 | 2 |- | {{flag|SLO}} | [[Blaž Kavčič]] | 102 | 3 |- | {{flag|RUS}} | [[Teymuraz Gabashvili]] | 109 | 4 |- | {{flag|ESP}} | [[Marcel Granollers]] | 114 | 5 |- | {{flag|ROU}} | [[Victor Crivoi]] | 115 | 6 |- | {{flag|ESP}} | [[Pere Riba]] | 119 | 7 |- | {{flag|POR}} | [[Rui Machado]] | 120 | 8 |} *Rankings are as of March 1, 2010.
===Other entrants=== The following players received wildcards into the singles main draw: * {{flagicon|MAR}} [[Rabie Chaki]] * {{flagicon|MAR}} [[Reda El Amrani]] * {{flagicon|MAR}} [[Hicham Khaddari]] * {{flagicon|MAR}} [[Mehdi Ziadi]]
The following players received entry from the qualifying draw: * {{flagicon|ITA}} [[Andrea Arnaboldi]] * {{flagicon|GER}} [[Bastian Knittel]] * {{flagicon|ESP}} [[Adrián Menéndez-Maceiras]] * {{flagicon|POR}} [[João Sousa]]
==Champions==
===Singles=== {{main|2010 Morocco Tennis Tour – Rabat – Singles}} {{flagicon|ESP}} '''[[Rubén Ramírez Hidalgo]]''' def. {{flagicon|ESP}} [[Marcel Granollers]], 6–4, 6–4
===Doubles=== {{main|2010 Morocco Tennis Tour – Rabat – Doubles}} {{flagicon|SRB}} '''[[Ilija Bozoljac]]''' / {{flagicon|ITA}} '''[[Daniele Bracciali]]''' def. {{flagicon|UKR}} [[Oleksandr Dolgopolov Jr.]] / {{flagicon|RUS}} [[Dmitri Sitak]], 6–4, 6–4
==External links== *[http://www.frmt.ma/frmt/index.php Morocco Tennis Tour official website]
{{2010 ATP Challenger Tour}}

[[Devonshire Cougars|Cougars]] 4-0 [[Flanagan's Onions|Onions]] | biggest away win = [[Flanagan's Onions|Onions]] 0-9 [[PHC Zebras|Zebras]] | highest scoring = [[Flanagan's Onions|Onions]] 0-9 [[PHC Zebras|Zebras]] | longest wins = | longest unbeaten = | longest winless = | longest losses = | highest attendance = | lowest attendance = | average attendance = | prevseason = [[2011–12 Bermudian Premier Division|2011–12]] | nextseason = [[2013–14 Bermudian Premier Division|2013–14]] }} The '''2012–13 [[Bermudian Premier Division]]''' is the 50th season of the highest competitive football league in [[Bermuda]], which was founded in 1963. ==Overview== The competition started in October 2012 and finished in March 2013. [[Dandy Town Hornets]] were the defending champions, having won their sixth league championship [[2011–12 Bermudian Premier Division|the season before]]. [[Devonshire Cougars]] won the league title in March 2013 when [[Somerset Trojans]] beat Cougars' sole challengers [[North Village Rams]] to pull Rams out of the title race.[http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20130311/SPORT01/703119959 Cougars clinch championship title] - Royal Gazette [[Robin Hood FC|Robin Hood]][http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20130325/SPORT01/703259966/hood-relegated-after-losing-to-village Hood relegated after losing to Village] - Royal Gazette and [[St. George’s Colts]] were relegated. ==Teams== {| class="wikitable" |- ! {{EngvarB|date=April 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2014}} {{Commonwealth Games infobox | Name = XXII Commonwealth Games | Logo = Birmingham_2022_Bid_Logo.png | size = 250px | Host city = [[Birmingham]], [[England]] | Nations participating = 73 Commonwealth nations (expected) | Athletes participating = ~5000 | Events = TBA in [[#Sports|18 sports]] | Opening ceremony = 27 July | Closing ceremony = 7 August | Queen's Baton = TBD | Stadium = [[Alexander Stadium]] | Motto = ''Heart of the UK, Soul of the Commonwealth'' | previous = [[2018 Commonwealth Games|XXI]] | next = [[2026 Commonwealth Games|XXIII]] | Website = |}} {{2022 Commonwealth Games}} The '''2022 Commonwealth Games''', officially known as the '''XXII Commonwealth Games''' and commonly known as '''Birmingham 2022''', is an international [[multi-sport event]] for members of the [[Commonwealth of Nations|Commonwealth]] that is scheduled to be held in [[Birmingham]], [[England]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/commonwealth-games/42437441|title=Commonwealth Games: Birmingham announced as host of 2022 event|date=2017-12-21|work=BBC Sport|access-date=2017-12-22|language=en-GB}} This is due to be the third time England has hosted the Games. The Games are expected to take place between 27 July and 7 August 2022. The city was announced as the host at a press conference at the Arena Academy in Birmingham on 21 December 2017.{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/2017/12/21/birmingham-named-2022-commonwealth-games-host-city/|title=Birmingham named 2022 Commonwealth Games host city|last=Sport|first=Telegraph|date=2017-12-21|work=The Telegraph|access-date=2017-12-22|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}} ==Host selection== {{main article|Bids for the 2022 Commonwealth Games}} === First selection === Two cities initially launched bids for the games; [[Durban]], [[South Africa]] and [[Edmonton|Edmonton, Alberta]], [[Canada]]. Edmonton withdrew its bid in February 2015, leaving Durban as the only bid to go forward to CGF General Assembly in September 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.euronews.com/2015/02/11/edmonton-withdraws-bid-for-2022-commonwealth-games/ |title=Edmonton withdraws bid for 2022 Commonwealth Games | euronews, world news |publisher=Euronews.com |date= |accessdate=2015-08-11}} The coastal South African city of [[Durban]] initially secured the right to host the games, as they were the sole bidder for the event. The city previously considered bidding for the [[2020 Summer Olympics|2020]] or [[2024 Summer Olympics]]. ====Withdrawal of Durban as host==== It was reported in February 2017 that [[Durban]] may be unable to host the games due to financial constraints.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-39116534|title=Commonwealth Games 2022: Durban 'may drop out as host'|date=2017-02-28|work=BBC News|access-date=2017-07-06|language=en-GB}} This was confirmed one month later on 13 March 2017 when the [[Commonwealth Games Federation]] (CGF) stripped Durban of their rights to host the games.{{Cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/sport/commonwealth-games/durban-stripped-of-2022-commonwealth-games-20170313-guxc9d.html|title=Durban stripped of 2022 Commonwealth Games|date=2017-03-14|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|access-date=2017-07-06|language=en-US}} It would have marked the first time the games were held in [[Africa]] and the second time a [[Republics in the Commonwealth of Nations|Commonwealth republic]] would have hosted, following [[Delhi]], [[India]] in [[2010 Commonwealth Games|2010]]. The games were set to open on the 18 July 2022, coinciding with the birthday of the late South African President, [[Nelson Mandela]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.durban-2022.com/|title=Durban is #ReadyToInspire, are you?|website=Durban-2022|language=en|access-date=2017-07-06}} === Second selection === A new bidding process was launched, where [[Liverpool]] and [[Birmingham]] expressed their interests in hosting the games.{{cite news|last1=Rumsby|first1=Ben|title=Liverpool and Birmingham battle to host Commonwealth Games 2022|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/2017/03/13/liverpool-birmingham-battle-host-commonwealth-games-2022/|accessdate=14 March 2017|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=13 March 2017}} On 14 March 2017, [[Manchester]], who previously hosted the [[2002 Commonwealth Games]], expressed their interest in hosting the games.{{cite news|last1=Williams|first1=Jennifer|title=Manchester in discussions to host the 2022 Commonwealth Games|url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/greater-manchester-news/manchester-discussions-hold-2022-commonwealth-12742043|accessdate=14 March 2017|work=[[Manchester Evening News]]|date=14 March 2017}} In September 2017, Birmingham beat Liverpool for the recommended bid for England.{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/general/athletics/commonwealth-games-birmingham-beats-liverpool-become-uk-candidate-bid-a7934286.html|title=Birmingham beats Liverpool for hosting the 2022 commonwealth games|website=www.independent.co.uk|publisher=The Independent|accessdate=7 September 2017}} With Birmingham being the sole bidder for the event they won the right to stage the Games.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/commonwealth-games/41185554|title=Birmingham beats Liverpool to become UK candidate for potential 2022 Commonwealth bid|date=7 September 2017|publisher=|via=www.bbc.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.insidethegames.biz/articles/1052997/commonwealth-games-england-to-reveal-2022-candidate-city-in-September|title=Commonwealth Games England to reveal 2022 candidate city in September|publisher=Inside the Game|date=20 July 2017|accessdate=21 December 2017}} However, it was announced that the bid was not fully compliant, and the bidding process was extended until 30 November 2017.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/41525305|title=Commonwealth Games 2022: Birmingham bid 'not fully compliant'|date=6 October 2017|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}} The CGF had 170 questions regarding Birmingham's bid.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/41823005|title=Commonwealth Games Federation had '170 queries' over Birmingham's 2022 bid|date=31 October 2017|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}} ====Birmingham awarded as replacement host==== On 21 December 2017, Birmingham was awarded for the 2022 Games as Durban's replacement host. Louise Martin, president of the [[Commonwealth Games Federation]], made the official announcement at a press conference at the Arena Academy in Birmingham. {| class="wikitable" ! colspan="7" |2022 Commonwealth Games bidding results |- !City !Nation !Votes |- |'''[[Birmingham]]''' |'''{{Flag|England}}''' | align="center" |'''Unanimous''' |} == Venues == Birmingham has a wealth of existing sports venues, arenas and conference halls that are ideal for hosting sport during the Games. 95% of the competition venues are already in place for the 2022 games.{{Cite web|url=http://www.birmingham2022.com/|title=Birmingham 2022 Heart of the UK, Soul of the Commonwealth|website=www.birmingham2022.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-08-14}} [[Alexander Stadium]] which is scheduled to host the ceremonies and athletics is planned to be renovated and the capacity increased to 50,000 seats. A new 400 metre warm up track is also planned. This would leave the stadium well placed to become the home of [[UK Athletics]], hosting all the major national and international competitions after the Games.{{Cite news|url=http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/news/midlands-news/how-alexander-stadium-transformed-birmingham-13259753|title=See how Alexander Stadium could be transformed for Commonwealth Games|last=Elkes|first=Neil|date=2017-06-30|work=birminghammail|access-date=2017-08-14}} [[File:Genting_Arena.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Genting_Arena.jpg|thumb|[[Genting Arena]]]] [[File:Symphony_Hall_Birmingham.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Symphony_Hall_Birmingham.jpg|thumb|[[Symphony Hall, Birmingham|Symphony Hall]]]] [[File:2012_Community_Shield.JPG|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:2012_Community_Shield.JPG|thumb|[[Villa Park]]]] === Venues in Birmingham and the West Midlands area === {| class="wikitable sortable" !Venue !Sport !Capacity !Status |- |[[Alexander Stadium]] |Ceremonies Athletics |50,000 |Upgrade |- |[[National Exhibition Centre]] |Boxing Judo Table Tennis Freestyle Wrestling |5,000 |Existing |- |- |[[Genting Arena]] |Badminton |15,000 |Existing |- |[[Arena Birmingham]] |Artistic and Rhythmic Gymnastics |15,000 |Existing |- |[[Symphony Hall, Birmingham|Symphony Hall]] |Weightlifting |2,200 |Existing |- |[[University of Birmingham]] |Squash Hockey |5,000 |Existing |- |Sandwell Aquatics Centre |Swimming Diving |5,000 |New |- |[[Villa Park]] |Rugby 7s |42,000 |Existing |- |[[Victoria Square, Birmingham|Victoria Square]]{{Cite web|url=https://www.expressandstar.com/news/local-hubs/birmingham/2017/08/14/birminghams-victoria-square-could-host-basketball-in-2022-commonwealth-games/|title=How Birmingham's Victoria Square would look hosting basketball in 2022 Commonwealth Games|last=Cosgrove|first=David|website=www.expressandstar.com|language=en|access-date=2017-08-14}} |Basketball 3x3 |3,000 |Existing |- |[[Ricoh Arena#Ericsson Exhibition Hall|Ericsson Indoor Arena, Coventry]] |Netball |7,000 |Existing |- |{{nowrap|[[Victoria Park, Leamington Spa|Victoria Park, Leamington Spa]]{{Cite news|url=http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/news/midlands-news/lawn-bowls-venue-announced-birminghams-13492605|title=Lawn bowls venue unveiled for city's 2022 Commonwealth Games bid|last=Elkes|first=Neil|date=2017-08-17|work=birminghammail|access-date=2017-08-17}}}} |Bowls |2,000 |Existing |- |[[Edgbaston Cricket Ground]] |Cricket |25,000 |Existing |} === Venues outside West Midlands === {| class="wikitable sortable" !Venue !Sport !Capacity !Status |- |[[Lee Valley VeloPark|Lee Valley VeloPark, London]] |Cycling (track) |6,000 |Existing |} == Sports == On 22 December 2017, the BBC Reported that the organisers of the games are currently in talks with the [[International Cricket Council]] (ICC) about the inclusion of women's cricket. It was also reported that shooting is likely to be excluded from the games citing a lack of facilities around Birmingham, if this is true it will be the first time since 1970 where shooting has not been included in the games.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/commonwealth-games/42458483|title=Birmingham 2022: Four unanswered questions for the Commonwealth Games|date=2017-12-22|work=BBC Sport|access-date=2017-12-23|language=en-GB}} The dropping of shooting from the games programme was confirmed by the [[Commonwealth Games Federation]] CEO, David Grevemberg in January 2018.{{Cite news|url=http://aroundtherings.com/site/A__62549/Title__Optional-Sports-at-2022-Commonwealth-Games/292/Articles|title=Optional Sports at 2022 Commonwealth Games|date=2018-01-18|work=Around the Rings|access-date=2018-01-20|language=en-GB}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/shooting/42753120|title=Birmingham 2022: Shooting dropped from Commonwealth Games|date=2018-01-19|work=BBC|access-date=2018-01-20|language=en-GB}}{{Cite news|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/sports/sport-others/no-shooting-at-commonwealth-games-top-official-suggests-t20-mixed-cricket-4993578/|title=No shooting at 2022 Commonwealth Games, top official suggests T20 mixed cricket|date=2018-01-19|work=Indian Express|access-date=2018-01-20|language=en-ID}} In November 2018,the ICC confirmed that they have submitted a bid to include women's cricket in Birmingham.{{cite web|url=https://www.icc-cricket.com/media-releases/922079 |title=ICC bids for Women's Cricket in Commonwealth Games |work=International Cricket Council |accessdate=26 {{unreferenced|date=April 2015}} {{Infobox ski jumping hill | hill_name = Aigner-Schanze | nickname = | image = 20150207 Skispringen Hinzenbach 4194.jpg | caption = | location = | city = [[Hinzenbach]] | country = [[Austria]] | opened = 2010 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | size = | k-spot = K-85 | hill size = HS 94 | hill record = 100 m (328 ft)
{{flagicon|AUT}} [[Markus Eggenhofer]]
(6 Feb 2011) | championships = | olympics = | world championships = }} '''Aigner-Schanze''' (official: '''Energie AG-Skisprung Arena''') are [[ski jumping]] hills in [[Hinzenbach]], [[Austria]]. [[File:Hinzenbach Schanze 1887.jpg|thumb|260px|All hills (K-15, K-30, K-70 and K-95)]] ==History== First hill was opened in 1930s and owned by Union Volksbank Hinzenbach. In 2006 construction for Aigner-Schanze (normal hill) began and on 9 October 2010 it was officially opened. Every Year Aigner-Schanze hosted [[Fédération Internationale de Ski|FIS]] [[Ski jumping World Cup]] events for ladies. It also hosted [[FIS Grand Prix Ski Jumping|Summer Grand Prix]] events. [[Markus Eggenhofer]] holds the hill record. There are also three smaller hills K-10, K-20 and K-40. {{coord missing|Austria}} [[Category:Ski jumping venues in Austria]] [[Category:Sport in Austria]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1924]]

revision.text:
{{redirect|Cue ball|the video game|Jimmy White's 2: Cueball|things called "Q-ball"|Q-ball (disambiguation)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2012}} [[File:Billiard ball comparison.jpg|thumb|200px|{{Cuegloss|Cue ball|Cue balls}} from (left to right): {{unordered list | [[Russian pyramid]] and [[Kaisa (billiards)|kaisa]]—68 mm ({{frac|2|11|16}} in) | [[Carom billiards|Carom]]—61.5 mm ({{frac|2|7|16}} in) | International [[pool (cue sports)|pool]]—57.15 mm ({{frac|2|1|4}} in) | [[Blackball (pool)|British-style]] pool (large) —56 mm ({{frac|2|3|16}} in) | [[Snooker]]—52.5 mm ({{frac|2|1|15}} in) | British-style pool (regular)—51 mm (2 in) }} Not shown: miniature pool—approximately 38 mm ({{frac|1|1|2}} in).]]
A '''billiard ball''' is a small, hard [[ball]] used in [[cue sports]], such as [[carom billiards]], [[Pool (cue sports)|pool]], and [[snooker]]. The number, type, diameter, color, and pattern of the balls differ depending upon the specific game being played. Various particular ball properties such as [[hardness]], [[friction coefficient]] and [[Resilience (materials science)|resilience]] are important to accuracy.
==History== Early balls were made of various materials, including wood and clay (the latter remaining in use well into the 20th century). Although affordable [[ox]]-bone balls were in common use in Europe,<ref name="ebay">Note: Antique ox-bone balls remain a very common item on [[eBay]].</ref> elephant [[ivory]] was favored since at least 1627 until the early 20th century;<ref name="Shamos 1999">{{Shamos 1999}}</ref>{{rp|17}} the earliest known written reference to ivory billiard balls is in the 1588 inventory of the [[Duke of Norfolk]].<ref name="Everton 1986">{{Cite book |title=The History of Snooker and Billiards |last=Everton |first=Clive |authorlink=Clive Everton |location=Haywards Heath, UK |publisher=[[Transworld (company)|Partridge Pr.]] |page=8 |year=1986 |isbn=1-85225-013-5 |edition=rev. ver. of ''The Story of Billiards and Snooker'', 1979 |quote=11 balls of {{sic|hide=y|yvery}} }}</ref> By the mid-19th century, elephants were being slaughtered for their ivory at an alarming rate, just to keep up with the demand for high-end billiard balls – no more than eight balls could be made from a single elephant's tusks.{{citation needed|date=February 2010|reason=When sourced, this should probably be added to the article on elephants.}} Dyed and numbered balls appeared around the early 1770s.<ref name="Shamos 1999" />{{rp|17}} The billiard industry realized that the supply of elephants (their primary source of ivory) was [[endangered species|endangered]], as well as dangerous to obtain (the latter an issue of notable public concern at the turn of the 19th century).<ref name="Shamos 1999" />{{rp|17}} Inventors were challenged to come up with an alternative material that could be [[Manufacturing|manufactured]], with a [[United States dollar|US$]]10,000 prize being offered by a New York supplier,<ref name="Shamos 1999" />{{rp|17}} [[Michael Phelan (billiards)|Phelan]] and [[H. W. Collender|Collender]].{{Citation needed|date=February 2010|reason=Can't find reliable source for company name.}} (This would be worth approximately ${{formatnum:{{Inflation|US|10000|1869|r=1}}}} in {{CURRENTYEAR}}{{Inflation-fn|US}}.)
Although not the first artificial substance to be used for the balls (e.g. [[Sorel cement]], invented in 1867, was marketed as an artificial ivory), [[John Wesley Hyatt]] invented a composition material in 1869 called [[nitrocellulose]] for billiard balls (US patent 50359, the first American patent for billiard balls). It is unclear if the cash prize was ever awarded<!--to anyone, that is-->, and there is no evidence suggesting he did in fact win it.<ref name="Shamos 1999" />{{rp|17}}<ref name="Plastiquarian">{{cite web |url=http://www.plastiquarian.com/hyatt.htm |title=Hyatt |author= |year=2002 |work=Plastiquarian.com |location=London |publisher=[[Plastics Historical Society]] |accessdate=26 February 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071221114457/http://www.plastiquarian.com/hyatt.htm |archivedate=21 December 2007 |df=dmy }}</ref> By 1870 it was commercially branded [[Celluloid]], the first industrial plastic. However, the nature of celluloid made it volatile in production, occasionally exploding, which ultimately made this early plastic impractical.<ref name="Shamos 1999" />{{rp|17}} Subsequently, to avoid the problem of celluloid instability, the industry experimented with various other synthetic materials for billiard balls such as [[Bakelite]], [[Poly(methyl methacrylate)|Crystallite]] and other plastic compounds.
The exacting requirements of the billiard ball are met today with balls cast from plastic materials that are strongly resistant to cracking and chipping. Currently [[Saluc]], under the brand names Aramith and Brunswick Centennial, manufactures [[phenolic resin]] balls.<ref>[http://www.saluc.com/html/billiard/index.php Aramith]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.brunswickbilliards.com/our_rich_history/billiard_balls/index.html|title=History|work=brunswickbilliards.com|access-date=9 February 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140327190020/http://www.brunswickbilliards.com/our_rich_history/billiard_balls/index.html|archive-date=27 March 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Other plastics and resins such as [[polyester]] (under various trade names) and clear [[Acrylic glass|acrylic]] are also used, by competing companies such as Elephant Balls Ltd.<ref>[http://www.ElephantBalls.com Elephant Balls Ltd.]</ref> and Frenzy Sports.<ref>[http://www.FrenzySports.com/productinfo.htm Frenzy Sports] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160107092229/http://www.frenzysports.com/productinfo.htm |date=7 January 2016 }}</ref>
Ivory balls remained in use in [[artistic billiards]] competition until the late 20th century.<ref name="Shamos 1999" />{{rp|17}}
==Types==
===Carom billiards=== [[File:Carom billiards balls.jpg|thumb|200px|Carom balls, [[Four-ball billiards|four-ball]] needs an additional object ball.]] In the realm of [[carom billiards]] (or carambole) games, three balls are used to play [[straight-rail]], [[three-cushion]], [[balkline and straight rail|balkline]], [[Five-pin billiards|five-pins]], and related games on pocketless [[billiards table]]s. The exception is [[Four-ball billiards|four-ball]] which needs an extra object ball. Carom balls are not numbered, and at 61–61.5 mm (between approximately {{frac|2|3|8}} and {{frac|2|7|16}} in) in diameter<ref name="UMB-II-12-2">{{cite web |url=http://www.umb.org/Rules/Carom_Rules.pdf |format=PDF |title=World Rules of {{sic|hide=y|Carom Billiard|reason=Yes, UMB did leave off the "s" in "Billiards".}} |at=Chapter II ("Equipment"), Article 12 ("Balls, Chalk"), Section 2 |work=UMB.org |author= |publisher=[[Union Mondiale de Billard]] |location=Sint-Martens-Latem, Belgium |date=1 January 1989 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928031638/http://www.umb.org/Rules/Carom_Rules.pdf |archivedate=28 September 2007 |accessdate=5 March 2007 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} Officially but somewhat poorly translated version, from the French original.</ref> are larger than pool balls. The 61.5 mm size are more common. They are typically colored as follows:
:* Red {{Cuegloss|Object ball|object ball}} (or, uncommonly, blue; two object balls are used in [[Four-ball billiards|four-ball]]) :* White {{Cuegloss|Cue ball|cue ball}} for player 1 :* White with a spot (or sometimes yellow) cue ball for player 2
===Pool=== {{anchor|American-style pool}} {|class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%;float:left; margin:1em 2em 1em 0em;" |- |align=center|1||bgcolor="gold" colspan=3| ||yellow |- |align=center|2||bgcolor="blue" colspan=3| ||blue |- |align=center|3||bgcolor="red" colspan=3| ||red |- |align=center|4||bgcolor="blueviolet" colspan=3| ||purple <small>(pink in TV ball sets, see below for the reason)</small> |- |align=center|5||bgcolor="orangered" colspan=3| ||orange |- |align=center|6||bgcolor="forestgreen" colspan=3| ||green |- |align=center|7||bgcolor="brown" colspan=3| ||brown or maroon <small>(tan in TV ball sets)</small> |- |align=center|8||bgcolor="black" colspan=3| ||black |- |align=center|9||bgcolor="white"| ||bgcolor="gold"| ||bgcolor="white"| ||yellow and white |- |align=center|10||bgcolor="white"| ||bgcolor="blue"| ||bgcolor="white"| ||blue and white |- |align=center|11||bgcolor="white"| ||bgcolor="red"| ||bgcolor="white"| ||red and white |- |align=center|12||bgcolor="white"| ||bgcolor="blueviolet"| ||bgcolor="white"| ||purple and white <small>(pink and white in TV ball sets)</small> |- |align=center|13||bgcolor="white"| ||bgcolor="orangered"| ||bgcolor="white"| ||orange and white |- |align=center|14||bgcolor="white"| ||bgcolor="forestgreen"| ||bgcolor="white"| ||green and white |- |align=center|15||bgcolor="white"| ||bgcolor="brown"| ||bgcolor="white"| ||brown, or maroon, and white <small>(tan and white in TV ball sets)</small> |- |align=center|•||bgcolor="white" colspan=3| ||{{Cuegloss|Cue ball|cue ball}}, white or off-white <small>(sometimes with one or more spots)</small> |} {{Multiple image |total_width=400 |image1=Bicentennial Billard Balls.jpg |caption1=Old style [[Brunswick Corporation|Brunswick]] pool balls, the numbers are not located on the stripe |image2=Cribbage pool rack closeup.jpg |caption2=Modern style [[Saluc|Super Aramith Pro]] pool balls racked in [[Cribbage (pool)|Cribbage]] arrangement }} Pool balls are used to play various [[Pool (cue sports)|pool]] (pocket billiards or pool billiards) games, such as [[eight-ball]], [[nine-ball]] and [[one-pocket]]. In North America and Asia, they are referred to simply as "billiard balls" (except among carom and snooker players). These balls, used the most widely throughout the world, are considerably smaller than carom billiards balls, slightly larger than British-style pool balls and substantially larger than those for snooker. According to [[World Pool-Billiard Association|WPA]]/[[Billiard Congress of America|BCA]] equipment specifications, the weight may be from {{cvt|5.5|to(-)|6.0|oz|g}} with a diameter of {{cvt|2.250|in|mm}}, plus or minus {{cvt|0.005|in|mm|3}}.<ref name="WPAequipspec">{{cite web |url=http://www.wpa-pool.com/web/WPA_Tournament_Table_Equipment_Specifications |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130928165510/http://www.wpa-pool.com/web/WPA_Tournament_Table_Equipment_Specifications |archivedate=2013-09-28 |title=WPA Tournament Table & Equipment Specifications |work=WPA-Pool.com |publisher=World Pool-Billiard Association |date=November 2001 }}</ref><ref name="BCAbook">{{cite book | year = 2004 | title = Billiards: The Official Rules and Records Book | publisher = [[Billiards Congress of America]] | location = [[Colorado Springs, Colorado|Colorado Springs]] | page = 5 | isbn = 978-1-878493-14-9 | author = BCA Rules Committee }}</ref> These are often referred to as {{convert|2+1/4|in|mm|adj=on}} balls. The balls are numbered and colored as in the table. [[File:Baseball pool balls and rack.png|thumb|Extended set for [[baseball pocket billiards]].]] In [[baseball pocket billiards]], the ball set is extended to 21 balls, in which the 16 ball is black and white, while balls 17 through 21 have no special design, but look exactly like balls 9 through 13, respectively, except for their numbers.
Balls 1 through 7 are often referred to as {{Cuegloss|Solids|solids}} and 9 through 15 as {{Cuegloss|Stripes|stripes}} though there are many other colloquial terms for each {{Cuegloss|Suit|suit}} of balls (highs and lows, etc.). Striped balls were introduced around 1889.<ref name="Shamos 1999" />{{rp|246}} Though it looks similar to the solids, the 8 ball is not considered a solid because it is the only ball that is black. Some games such as nine-ball do not distinguish between stripes and solids, but rather use the numbering on the balls to determine which {{Cuegloss|Object ball|object ball}} must be pocketed. In other games such as [[three-ball]] and [[straight pool]] neither type of marking is of any consequence. In eight-ball, straight pool, and related games, all sixteen balls are employed. In the games of [[seven-ball]], nine-ball, [[ten-ball]] and related, only object balls 1 through 7, 9 and 10, respectively (plus the cue ball) are used.
Some balls used in televised pool games are colored differently in order to make them distinguishable on television monitors. Specifically, the 4 ball is colored pink instead of dark purple, and the 12 is white with a pink stripe, to make it easier to distinguish their color from the black 8 ball, and similarly the 7 and 15 balls use a light tan color instead of a deep brown. Television was also the genesis of the cue ball with six red spots on its surface (known as a "measle" cue ball) so that {{Cuegloss|Spin|spin}} placed on it is evident to viewers.
Coin-operated pool tables such as those found at [[Bar (establishment)|bars]] historically have often used either a larger ("mudball") or denser ceramic weighted cue ball, such that its extra weight makes it easy for the cue ball return mechanism to separate it from object balls (which are captured until the game ends and the table is paid again for another game) so that the cue ball can be returned for further play, should it be accidentally potted. In Asia and Europe, some pool tables use a smaller cue ball instead. Modern tables usually employ a magnetic ball of regulation or near-regulation size and weight, since players have complained for many decades that the heavy and often oversized cue balls do not "play" correctly.<!--R. Givens's "Eight-ball Bible" can be cited on these points, but my copy is missing. -SMcCandlish-->
===British-style pool (blackball)=== [[File:SetUpofTriangleForStandardPool.jpg|left|thumb|145px|Setup for blackball]] In WPA [[Blackball (pool)|blackball]] and its predecessor [[World Eight-ball Pool Federation|WEPF]] or ''English eight-ball pool'' (not to be confused with the games of eight-ball or English billiards), fifteen object balls again are used, but fall into two unnumbered {{Cuegloss|Group|groups}}, the {{Cuegloss|Red ball|reds}} (or less commonly {{Cuegloss|Blue ball|blues}}) and {{Cuegloss|Yellow ball|yellows}}, with a white cue ball, and black 8 ball. Aside from the 8, shots are not {{Cuegloss|Call-shot|called}} since there is no reliable way to identify particular balls to be pocketed. Because they are unnumbered they are wholly unsuited to certain pool games, such as nine-ball, in which ball order is important. They are noticeably smaller than the American-style balls, and with a cue ball that is slightly smaller than the object balls, while the table's {{Cuegloss|Pocket|pockets}} are tighter to compensate. Neither the WPA nor the WEPF (publicly) define ball or even table dimensions, though presumably{{cn|date=August 2017}} league and tournament organizers are given some guidelines in this regard. Most manufacturers that supply this market provide sets that range from {{convert|2|in|mm|0}} up to {{convert|2+3/16|in|mm|0}}, often with a slightly smaller cue ball, e.g. {{cvt|1+7/8|in|mm|0}} for a 2-inch set. The most common object ball diameters are {{cvt|2|in|mm|0}} and {{cvt|2+1/8|in|mm|0}}. The yellow-and-red sets are sometimes commercially referred to as "casino sets" (they were formerly used for televised eight-ball championships,<ref name="Shamos 1999"/>{{rp|45}} most often held in casinos). The use of such sets, however, predates television, as they were used for B.B.C. Co. Pool, the forerunner of modern eight-ball, at least as early as 1908.<ref name="Shamos 1999" />{{rp|24}}
===Snooker=== [[File:Set of Snookerballs.png|thumb|right|300px|Complete set of snooker balls.]] {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%;float:left; margin:1em 2em 1em 0em;" |- !Colour!!Value |- | [[File:Snooker_ball_red.png|14px]] {{Cuegloss|Red ball|Red}}|| 1 point |- | [[File:Snooker_ball_yellow.png|14px]] {{Cuegloss|Yellow ball|Yellow}} || 2 points |- | [[File:Snooker_ball_green.png|14px]] {{Cuegloss|Green ball|Green}} || 3 points |- | [[File:Snooker_ball_brown.png|14px]] {{Cuegloss|Brown ball|Brown}} || 4 points |- | [[File:Snooker_ball_blue.png|14px]] {{Cuegloss|Blue ball|Blue}} || 5 points |- | [[File:Snooker_ball_pink.png|14px]] {{Cuegloss|Pink ball|Pink}} || 6 points |- | [[File:Snooker_ball_black.png|14px]] {{Cuegloss|Black ball|Black}} || 7 points |} Ball sets for the sport of snooker look at first glance like a mixture of American- and British-style pool balls. There are twenty-two balls in total, arranged as a rack of 15 unmarked reds, six {{Cuegloss|Colour ball|colour balls}} placed at various predetermined spots on the table, and a white cue ball. ''(See [[snooker]] for more information on ball setup.)''
The colour balls are sometimes numbered American-style, with their point values, for the amateur/home market, as follows in the adjacent table.
Snooker balls are technically standardized at {{cvt|52.5|mm|in|2}} in diameter within a tolerance of plus or minus {{cvt|0.05|mm|in|3}}. No standard weight is defined, but all balls in the set must be the same weight within a tolerance of {{cvt|3|g|oz|2}}.<ref name="WSAequipspec">[http://www.worldsnooker.com/equipment.htm "Equipment"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080801105033/http://www.worldsnooker.com/equipment.htm |date=1 August 2008 }}, World Snooker Association, publication date unknown (Retrieved 28 January 2007), London, UK.</ref> However, many sets are actually {{cvt|2+1/16|in|mm|1}}, even from major manufacturers. Snooker sets are also available with considerably smaller-than-regulation balls (and even with ten instead of fifteen reds) for play on smaller tables (down to half-size), and are sanctioned for use in some amateur leagues. Sets for [[Snooker|American snooker]] are typically {{cvt|2+1/8|in|mm|1}}, with numbered colour balls. {{clear left}}
The set of eight colours used for snooker balls (including white) are thought to be derived from the game of [[croquet]]. Snooker was invented in 1884 by [[Neville Francis Fitzgerald Chamberlain|British Army officers]] stationed in India. Croquet reached its peak popularity at the same time, particularly amongst people in the same social context. The eight coloured balls of croquet use the same identical set of eight colours. There are many other similarities between croquet and snooker, which when taken together, suggest that the derivation of the latter owes much to the existence of the former.<ref>{{cite web|title=An Introduction to Croquet: A Brief History|url=https://www.croquet.org.uk/?p=tech/CroquetIntro#history|publisher=The Croquet Association (of England and Wales)|accessdate=13 May 2017}}</ref>
===Other games=== {{Multiple image |total_width=400 |image1=Russian billiards ball at a corner pocket.jpg |caption1=Russian pyramid ball at a corner pocket. The relative size of the ball and the pocket makes the game very challenging. |image2=Golfbiljart Doel.jpg |caption2=Bumper pool ball near a pocket. The bumpers increase the difficulty in potting the ball. }} Various other games have their own variants of billiard balls. [[English billiards]] balls are like carom balls but are the same size as snooker balls. [[Russian pyramid]] uses a set of fifteen numbered but otherwise all-white balls, and a red or yellow cue ball that may be even larger than carom billiards balls at 68 mm (2<sup>11</sup>⁄<sub>16</sub> in) or 72 mm (2<sup>4</sup>⁄<sub>5</sub> in). The related game [[kaisa (billiards)|kaisa]] has the same pocket and ball dimensions but uses only five balls: one yellow, two red and two cue balls, one for each player.<ref name="BVRP">{{Cite web |url=https://cuesup.com/russian-pyramid-pool-a-game-bearing-more-games/ |title=Russian Billiards|work=CuesUp.com |author=<!--Staff writer; no byline.--> |year=2016 |accessdate=2016-12-28 }}</ref> [[Bumper pool]] requires four white and four red object balls, and two special balls, one red with a white spot and the other white with red spot; all are usually {{frac|2|1|8}} inch (approximately 52.5 mm) in diameter. [[Bar billiards]] uses six or seven white balls (depending on regional variations) and one red ball {{cvt|1+7/8|in|mm|0}} in diameter.
===Training balls=== [[File:Jim Rempe practice ball.jpg|thumb|150px|left|The [[Jim Rempe]] Training Ball]] Several brands of practice balls exist, which have systems of spots, stripes, differently colored halves and/or targeting rings.
For example, Saluc markets several practice ball systems, including the Jim Rempe Training Ball, a {{Cuegloss|Cue ball|cue ball}} marked with rings and targets on the surface of the ball so that the practicing player can better judge the effects of very particular amounts of {{Cuegloss|Sidespin|sidespin}}, {{Cuegloss|Topspin|topspin}}, {{Cuegloss|Backspin|backspin}} and other forms of cue ball control, and learn better control of [[Cue stick|cue]] {{Cuegloss|Stroke|stroke}}.<ref name="Saluc 1">{{Cite web|url= http://www.saluc.com/html/index.php?idlien=17 |title=Product Line > Training Balls|year=2005|work=Saluc.com|publisher=[[Saluc|Saluc S.A.]]|location=Callenelle, Belgium|accessdate=2008-02-18}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> Various competing products, such as several other Saluc models<ref name="Saluc 1" /> and Elephant Practice Balls,<ref name="Elephant">{{Cite web|url= http://www.elephantballs.com/store/products/22 |title=Elephant Practice Balls|year=2007|work=ElephantBalls.com|publisher=Elephant Balls, Ltd.|location=Columbus, Ohio|accessdate=2008-02-18}}</ref> use a similar aiming system. Some such sets consist of just a special cue ball and manual, while others also include an object ball marked for aiming practice. {{clear}} ===Novelty balls=== [[File:Novelty billiard balls.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Various novelty [[pocket billiards]] balls. Clockwise from the top: Red and white balls and markers from a proprietary game called Starball; an [[Elvis Presley]] commemorative cue ball from [[Graceland]]; a [[leopard]]-patterned 9 ball; colorful balls from a [[poker]]-themed set; regular balls and the small "jack" from a miniature [[bocce]] set used on a table instead of a lawn or court.]] There is a market for specialty cue balls and even entire ball sets, featuring sports team logos, cartoon characters, animal pelt patterns, etc.
Entrepreneurial inventors also supply a variety of novelty billiard games with unique rules and balls, some with playing card markings, others with stars and stripes, and yet others in sets of more than thirty balls in several suits. Marbled-looking and glittery materials are also popular for home tables. There are even [[blacklight]] sets for playing in near-dark. There are also [[practical joke]] cue and 8 balls, with off-center weights in them that make their paths curve and wobble. Miniature sets in various sizes (typically {{frac||2|3}} or {{frac||1|2}} of normal size) are also commonly available, primarily intended for undersized toy tables. Even an egg-shaped ball has been patented<ref>U.S. Patent No. 7,468,002</ref> and marketed under such names as Bobble Ball and Tag Ball.
==In popular culture== [[File:8 ball face.jpg|left|thumb|A [[Magic 8 Ball]]]] [[File:USS Sam Rayburn (SSBN-635) missile hatches.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Ballistic missile submarine]] {{USS|Sam Rayburn|SSBN-635|6}} displays a billiard motif on her missile hatches]] The 8 ball is frequently used iconically in Western, especially American, culture. It can often be found as an element of T-shirt designs, album covers and names, tattoos, household goods like paperweights and cigarette lighters, belt buckles, etc. A classic toy is the [[Magic 8-Ball]] "oracle". [[Don and Ron Harris|A wrestler]], [[Eightball & MJG|a rapper]], and [[8-Ball (band)|a rock band]] have all independently adopted the name. The term "8 ball" is also [[slang]] both for {{frac||1|8}} [[Ounce|oz.]] of [[cocaine]] or [[crystal methamphetamine|crystal meth]], and for a bottle of [[Olde English 800]] [[malt liquor]]. It has also been used to refer to African-Americans, particularly those of darker skin tones, as in the film ''[[Full Metal Jacket]]''. The expression "behind the eight [ball]" is used to indicate a [[dilemma]] from which it is difficult to extricate oneself. The term derives from the game kelly pool.<ref name="IEOB">{{cite book | last = Shamos | first = Michael Ian | year = 1993 | title = The Illustrated Encyclopedia of Billiards | publisher = Lyons & Burford | location = New York City | pages = 85, 128 and 168 | isbn = 1-55821-219-1}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last = Jewett | first = Bob |date=February 2002 | title = 8-Ball Rules: The many different versions of one of today's most common games | journal = Billiards Digest Magazine | pages = Pages 22–23}}</ref><ref>Ralph Hickok (2001). [http://www.hickoksports.com/history/billiard.shtml Sports History: Pocket Billiards] {{webarchive|url=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20020223060649/http://www.hickoksports.com/history/billiard.shtml |date=23 February 2002 }}. Retrieved 22 February 2007.</ref><ref>Billiard Congress America (1995–2005) [http://www.bca-pool.com/aboutus/history/start.shtml A Brief History of the Noble Game of Billiards] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070127151057/http://www.bca-pool.com/aboutus/history/start.shtml |date=27 January 2007 }} by Mike Shamos. Retrieved 22 February 2007.</ref><ref name="Mizerak">{{cite book | author= Steve Mizerak and Michael E. Panozzo | title = Steve Mizerak's Complete Book of Pool | publisher = Contemporary Books | location = [[Chicago|Chicago, Ill]] | pages = 127–8 | year = 1990 | isbn = 0-8092-4255-9}}</ref> In the ''[[Seinfeld]]'' episode "[[The Reverse Peephole]]", the character Puddy wears a jacket featuring the eight-ball.
Because the [[Collision#Billiards|collisions between billiard balls]] are nearly [[Elastic collision|elastic]], and the balls roll on a surface that produces low [[rolling friction]], their behavior is often used to illustrate [[Newton's laws of motion]]. Idealized, frictionless billiard balls are a staple of [[Mathematics|mathematical]] theorems and [[physics]] models, and figure in [[dynamical billiards]], [[scattering theory]], [[Lissajous knots]], [[billiard ball computing]] and [[Reversible cellular automaton|reversible cellular automata]], [[Polchinski's paradox]], [[contact dynamics]], [[collision detection]], the [[illumination problem]], [[Ultracold atom|atomic ultracooling]], [[quantum mirage]]s and elsewhere in these fields.
"Billiard balls" or "pool balls" is the name given to balls used in [[stage magic]] tricks, especially the classic "[[multiplying billiard balls]]". Though obviously derived from real billiard balls, today they are usually smaller, for easier manipulation and hiding, but not so small and light that they are difficult to [[juggle]], as the magic and juggling disciplines have often overlapped since their successful combination by pioneers like [[Paul Vandy]].
An urban legend received cultural attention to many saying, "If the [[Earth]] were the size of a billiard ball, it would be smoother". It was used in 2008's Discover Magazine,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/badastronomy/2008/09/08/ten-things-you-dont-know-about-the-earth/#.VpDO6I-cGCg |title=Ten things you don't know about the Earth |publisher=Bad Astronomy |date=8 September 2008 |accessdate=8 September 2008}}</ref> but mistook the diameter tolerance for smoothness. If the Earth were reduced to the size of a billiard ball, much of it, excluding the [[Himalayas]] and [[Mariana Trench]], would be smoother.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://billiards.colostate.edu/bd_articles/2013/june13.pdf |title=Is a Pool Ball Smoother than the Earth? |publisher=Billiards Digest |date=1 June 2013 |accessdate=26 November 2014}}</ref> (see also: [[Earth#Shape|Earth's Shape]])
The phrase "as smooth as a billiard ball" is sometimes applied to describe a [[Baldness|bald person]], and the term "cue ball" is also slang for someone who sports a [[shaved head]].
In [[Polandball]], numbered pool balls are used to denote aboriginal, prehistoric, or native peoples who do not have a flag of their own. Green 6-balls also denote [[extraterrestrial intelligence|extraterrestrials]].

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Asiad Main Stadium | nickname = | image = BusanAsiadStadium.jpg | location = 1459, [[Geoje-dong]], [[Yeonje-gu]], [[Busan]], [[South Korea]] | broke_ground = | opened = July 2001 | owner = | operator = | pitch_size = | construction_cost = 226.9 billion [[South Korean won|won]] | architect = | tenants = [[Busan IPark]] (2003–2016) | seating_capacity = 53,769 | highest attendance = }} '''Busan Asiad Stadium''' or '''Asiad Main Stadium''' is a multi-purpose stadium in [[Busan]], [[South Korea]], that was built for the [[2002 Asian Games]] and was also used for matches at the [[2002 FIFA World Cup]]. It has a capacity of 53,769. The stadium also hosted the opening and closing ceremonies of the 2002 Asian Games and was also the site of [[athletics (track and field)|athletics]] events during the Busan Asiad of 2002. Bella Vista]] | embedded = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> }} '''Estadio José Nasazzi''' is a multi-use [[stadium]] in [[Montevideo]], [[Uruguay]]. It is currently used primarily for [[football (soccer)|football]] matches. The stadium holds 15,000 people.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldstadiums.com/south_america/countries/uruguay.shtml|title=Stadiums in Uruguay|work=Worldstadiums.com|accessdate=8 September 2011}}</ref> It is the home stadium of [[C.A. Bella Vista]].

{{Refimprove|date=December 2009}} {{Infobox stadium |name = Estadio Olímpico |nickname = |logo_image = |logo_caption = |image = |caption = |fullname = Primer Estadio Olímpicohttp://media.photobucket.com/image/Estadio%20Ol%2525C3%2525ADmpico%20Riobamba/buenhombre/DSC01265.jpg |former_names = Primer Estadio Olímpico Municipal
Estadio Olímpico Municipal
Estadio Olímpico "Ciudad de Riobamba" |location = Avenida Carlos Zambrano S/N y Unidad Nacional
[[Riobamba]], [[Ecuador]] |coordinates = {{Coord|-1.666082|-78.659882|type:landmark|display=title}} |broke_ground = |built = |opened = {{Start date|1926|03|14}} |renovated = November 10, 1973
August 4, 1995 |expanded = |closed = |demolished = |owner = Federación Deportiva de Chimborazo |operator = Federación Deportiva de Chimborazo |surface = |scoreboard = |cost = |architect = |project_manager = |structural engineer = |services engineer = |general_contractor = |main_contractors = |capacity = 14,400http://www.cre.com.ec/noticias/2014/02/27/49393/cual-es-el-aforo-de-los-estadios-del-ecuador/ei |suites = |record_attendance = |dimensions = 100 x 66 m |acreage = |tenants = [[Centro Deportivo Olmedo|Olmedo]] |website = }} '''Estadio Olímpico''', commonly referred to as '''Estadio Olímpico de Riobamba''' to disambiguate it from other stadiums of a similar name, is a multi-use [[stadium]] in [[Riobamba]], [[Ecuador]]. It is currently used mostly for [[association football|football]] matches and is the home stadium of [[Centro Deportivo Olmedo|Olmedo]] in addition to other lower division clubs in the city. The stadium holds 14,400http://www.cre.com.ec/noticias/2014/02/27/49393/cual-es-el-aforo-de-los-estadios-del-ecuador/ei spectators and opened in 1926. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Estadio Olimpico De Riobamba}} [[Category:Football venues in Ecuador|Olimpico de Riobamba]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Chimborazo Province]] {{Ecuador-sports-venue-stub}}

revision.text:
{{see also|2005 in sports|Portal:Sports}} {{Events by month|2005|in sports}}__NOTOC__ {{Month year in topic|February 2005|sports|anchor=dmy}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2013}} {| class="infobox" style="width:18em" | ==Deaths== {{main article|Deaths in February 2005}} |} ==Events in sports==
===28 February 2005=== *[[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] basketball: [[Temple University]] announces that head men's basketball coach [[John Chaney (basketball coach)|John Chaney]] will not coach in the [[Atlantic 10 Conference]]'s tournament. This decision stems from an incident during a game against [[Saint Joseph's University]] on 24 February, when Chaney responded to the non-calling of illegal screens by Hawks players by sending in Temple center [[Nehemiah Ingram]] to commit hard fouls on Saint Joseph's center John Bryant. [http://www.signonsandiego.com/sports/college_basketball/20050301-0252-temple-chaney.html (San Diego ''Union-Tribune'')] [http://www.vindy.com/basic/sports/57986030942807.php (Youngstown ''Vindicator'')] [http://www.temple-news.com/sections/263990.html (Temple News)]
===27 February 2005=== *[[Cricket]]: South Africa (329 for 6) beat Zimbabwe (198 for 7) by 131 runs in the second [[One Day International]], [[Durban]], and now lead the three-match series 2–0. [http://uk.cricinfo.com/link_to_database/ARCHIVE/CRICKET_NEWS/2005/FEB/190499_RSAZIM2004-05_27FEB2005.html Wisden Cricinfo] *Cycling: [[George Hincapie]] wins [[Kuurne–Brussels–Kuurne]] by beating [[Kevin van Impe]] in a sprint with 2. *[[association football|Football]]: **[[UEFA Cup]] round of 32, second leg: [[Athletic Bilbao]] 1 – 2 '''[[FK Austria Wien|Austria Vienna]]''' [http://www.uefa.com/competitions/UEFACup/fixturesresults/round=1977/match=79947/Report=RP.html (UEFA.com)] **[[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] defeats [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] 3–2 after [[extra time]] to win the [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] at the [[Millennium Stadium]] in [[Cardiff]]. Chelsea manager [[José Mourinho]] is sent off by the fourth official for taunting Liverpool fans after Liverpool star [[Steven Gerrard]] scores an [[own goal]] in the 79th minute to level the match. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/4279679.stm (BBC)] **[[Premier League]] [[referee (association football)|referee]] [[Mike Dean (referee)|Mike Dean]] is suspended indefinitely after officials learn of his involvement in a [[betting]] website. [http://www.dailymail.co.uk/pages/live/articles/sport/football.html?in_article_id=339375&in_page_id=1779 (Daily Mail)] *[[NASCAR]]: [[Greg Biffle]] wins the [[Auto Club 500]] at the [[California Speedway]] from [[Jimmie Johnson]] and [[Kurt Busch]], with only 0.525 of a second separating the top three men. [http://www.nascar.com (NASCAR.com)] *[[Rugby union]]: In the final match of Round 3 of the [[2005 Six Nations Championship|Six Nations]], held [[Lansdowne Road|in Dublin]], [[Ireland national rugby union team|Ireland]] use a try from captain [[Brian O'Driscoll]] and 14 points from [[Ronan O'Gara]] to defeat [[England national rugby union team|England]] 19–13. The win keeps Ireland on track for a possible Grand Slam showdown with [[Wales national rugby union team|Wales]] [[Millennium Stadium|in Cardiff]] in three weeks. This also marks the first time since 1987 that England has lost three straight Six Nations matches. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/rugby_union/international/4297209.stm (BBC)] *[[Curling]]: In the final match of the [[2005 Scott Tournament of Hearts]], Manitoba, led by skip [[Jennifer Jones (curler)|Jennifer Jones]], defeats [[Jenn Hanna]]'s [[Ontario]] team 8–6 and becomes the Canadian national women's champion. With the win, Jones' rink has earned the right to represent Canada at the world championship, as well as an entry in the Canadian Olympic curling trials. [http://www.cbc.ca/story/sports/national/2005/02/27/Sports/hearts-final050228.xhtml (CBC sports)] [http://www.sportsnet.ca/curling/article.jsp?content=20050227_161044_772 (Sportsnet)]
===26 February 2005=== * [[Boxing]]: [[Miguel Cotto]] wins over [[Demarcus Corley]] by [[Knockout|TKO]] after Corley took a knee on the fifth round to avoid further punishment. Cotto's corner immediately tells Corley that they are at the disposal of giving him a rematch. *[[Cricket]]: [[Australia national cricket team|Australia]] (264 for 5) beat [[New Zealand national cricket team|New Zealand]] (178) by 86 runs in the third [[One Day International]], [[Auckland]], taking an unassailable 3–0 lead in the five-match series. [http://uk.cricinfo.com/link_to_database/ARCHIVE/CRICKET_NEWS/2005/FEB/189897_NZAUS2004-05_26FEB2005.html (Wisden Cricinfo)] *Cycling: [[Nick Nuyens]] (Belgium) wins the [[Omloop "Het Volk"]]. He finishes 14 seconds before the main group, of which his teammate [[Tom Boonen]] wins the sprint before [[Steven de Jongh]] and [[Niko Eeckhout]]. *[[Rugby union]], [[2005 Six Nations Championship|Six Nations]]: **[[Scotland national rugby union team|Scotland]] fails to score a try against [[Italy national rugby union team|Italy]], but six penalties by [[Chris Paterson]] provide all the points Scotland need to score its first win of this year's competition, 18–10, [[Murrayfield Stadium|in Edinburgh]]. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/rugby_union/international/4295853.stm (BBC)] **At [[Stade de France]] near Paris, [[France national rugby union team|France]] takes a 15–6 halftime lead over [[Wales national rugby union team|Wales]], but the Welsh storm back behind two [[Martyn Williams]] tries to score a 24–18 win, keeping Wales on course for a possible Grand Slam. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/rugby_union/international/4296101.stm (BBC)] *[[Curling]]: [[2005 Scott Tournament of Hearts]]: [[Ontario]]'s [[Jenn Hanna]] rink advance to the finals against [[Manitoba]] as they defeated [[British Columbia]]'s [[Kelly Scott]] rink 9–7 in the semi-final. [http://www.cbc.ca/story/sports/national/2005/02/26/Sports/hearts_semifinal050226.xhtml (CBC Sports)]
===25 February 2005=== *[[Lacrosse]]: **[[National Lacrosse League All-Star Game#2005|2005 NLL All Star Game]] ***East Division All Star Team 11–10 West Division All Star Team *[[Cricket]]: [[South Africa national cricket team|South Africa]] (301 for 7) beat [[Zimbabwe national cricket team|Zimbabwe]] (136) by 165 runs in the first [[One Day International]], [[Johannesburg]]. [http://uk.cricinfo.com/db/ARCHIVE/CRICKET_NEWS/2005/FEB/189340_RSAZIM2004-05_25FEB2005.html (Wisden Cricinfo)] *[[Curling]]: [[2005 Scott Tournament of Hearts]] – Defending Scott champion [[Colleen Jones]] fails to make it 5 championship wins in a row, as she was ousted by [[Sandy Comeau]]'s rink from [[New Brunswick]] in the morning tie-breaker. Comeau would then play [[Jenn Hanna]]'s [[Ontario]] rink who had beaten [[Alberta]]'s [[Cathy King]] rink in the other morning tie-breaker. Hanna would go on to win the final tie-breaker which determined the last playoff spot. In the evening, the page-playoffs began with Hanna once again winning, defeating [[Saskatchewan]]'s [[Stefanie Lawton]] rink in the 3–4 game for the right to go to the semi-final on Saturday. In the other playoff game, [[Manitoba]]'s [[Jennifer Jones (curler)|Jennifer Jones]] rink defeats [[British Columbia]]'s [[Kelly Scott]] rink in the 1–2 game, forcing Scott to play in the semi-final on Saturday and giving Jones a bye to the final on Sunday. [http://www.cbc.ca/story/sports/national/2005/02/25/Sports/jone-scott050225.xhtml (CBC sports)]
===24 February 2005=== *[[association football|Football]] – [[UEFA Cup]], round of 32: [http://www.uefa.com (UEFA.com)] **Second leg (advancing clubs in '''bold face'''): ***'''[[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]]''' 2 – 1 [[Grazer AK]] ***'''[[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]]''' 2 – 1 [[SC Heerenveen|Heerenveen]] ***'''[[Lille OSC|Lille]]''' 2 – 0 [[FC Basel]] ***[[VfB Stuttgart]] 0 – 2 '''[[Parma F.C.|Parma]]''' (after extra time) ***[[Feyenoord Rotterdam|Feyenoord]] 1 – 2 '''[[Sporting Clube de Portugal|Sporting Lisbon]]''' ***'''[[AZ Alkmaar]]''' 2 – 1 [[Alemannia Aachen|Alemannia]] ***[[FC Dnipro Dnipropetrovsk|Dnipro]] 0 – 1 '''[[FK Partizan|Partizan Belgrade]]''' ***'''[[FC Steaua București|Steaua Bucharest]]''' 2 – 0 [[Valencia CF|Valencia]] (after penalty shootout 4–3) ***'''[[AJ Auxerre|Auxerre]]''' 3 – 1 [[Ajax Amsterdam|Ajax]] ***[[S.L. Benfica|Benfica]] 1 – 1 '''[[PFC CSKA Moscow|CSKA Moscow]]''' ***'''[[Real Zaragoza]]''' 2 – 1 [[Fenerbahçe SK|Fenerbahçe]] ***'''[[Sevilla FC|Sevilla]]''' 2 – 0 [[Panathinaikos F.C.|Panathinaikos]] ***[[FC Schalke 04|Schalke 04]] 0 – 1 '''[[FC Shakhtar Donetsk|Shakhtar Donetsk]]''' ***[[FC Sochaux-Montbéliard|Sochaux]] 0 – 1 '''[[Olympiacos CFP|Olympiacos]]''' ***'''[[Villarreal CF|Villarreal]]''' 2 – 0 [[FC Dynamo Kyiv|Dynamo Kyiv]] **First leg (postponed from 16 February): ***[[FK Austria Wien|Austria Vienna]] 0 – 0 [[Athletic Bilbao]] **Fixtures for knock-out group of 16, to be played on 10 and 16–17 March: ***Middlesbrough – Sporting ***Sevilla – Parma ***Steaua Bucharest – Villarreal ***Lille – Auxerre ***Olympiacos – Newcastle ***Shakhtar – AZ ***Partizan Belgrade – CSKA Moscow ***Austria Vienna – Real Zaragoza (tie determined 27 February) * [[Curling]] – [[2005 Scott Tournament of Hearts]] – In the last day of the round robin, [[Manitoba]]'s [[Jennifer Jones (curler)|Jennifer Jones]] wins both of her games to finish first at 9–2. She will face [[British Columbia]]'s [[Kelly Scott]], who finished second at 8–3 in the "1–2" match-up, where the winner gets a bye to the final, and the loser must play in the semi-final. [[Saskatchewan]]'s [[Stefanie Lawton]] finished in third place with a 7–4 record and awaits the winner out of a massive tie for 6–5 which involves [[Ontario]]'s [[Jenn Hanna]], Alberta's [[Cathy King]], defending champion [[Colleen Jones]] and [[New Brunswick]]'s [[Sandy Comeau]]. 3 Tie-breaker games will be played to determine the winner, who will play Lawton in the "3–4" game. [http://www.cbc.ca/story/sports/national/2005/02/24/Sports/hearts050224.xhtml (CBC sports)]
===23 February 2005=== *[[association football|Football:]] [[UEFA Champions League]] knock-out round of 16, first leg: **[[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]] 2 – 1 [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/europe/4281719.stm (BBC)] **[[Werder Bremen]] 0 – 3 [[Olympique Lyonnais|Lyon]] [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/europe/4281733.stm (BBC)] **[[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] 0 – 1 [[A.C. Milan]] [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/europe/4281723.stm (BBC)] **[[Futebol Clube do Porto|Porto]] 1 – 1 [[Internazionale Milano F.C.|Inter Milan]] [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/europe/4281721.stm (BBC)] *[[Curling]] – [[2005 Scott Tournament of Hearts]]: On the second last day of the [[Round-robin tournament|round-robin]], [[Jennifer Jones (curler)|Jennifer Jones]]' [[Manitoba]] rink pulls out of her first place tie with [[Saskatchewan]], only needing one win against [[Alberta]] as Lawton lost both of hers. Jones has a 7–2 record while Lawton, along with Team Canada's [[Colleen Jones]] and [[British Columbia]]'s [[Kelly Scott]] sit in second place at a 6–3 record. The top 4 teams in the tournament make the playoffs. [http://www.cbc.ca/story/sports/national/2005/02/23/Sports/hearts_evening050223.xhtml (CBC sports)]
===22 February 2005=== *[[Cricket]]: [[Australia national cricket team|Australia]] (314 for 6) beat [[New Zealand national cricket team|New Zealand]] (208) by 106 runs in the second [[One Day International]]. They lead the five-match series 2–0. [http://nz.cricinfo.com/link_to_database/ARCHIVE/CRICKET_NEWS/2005/FEB/186833_NZAUS2004-05_22FEB2005.html (Wisden Cricinfo)] *[[association football|Football:]] [[UEFA Champions League]] knock-out round of 16, first leg: **[[Real Madrid]] 1 – 0 [[Juventus]] [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/europe/4281717.stm (BBC)] **[[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] 3 – 1 [[Bayer Leverkusen]] [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/europe/4281707.stm (BBC)] **[[PSV Eindhoven|PSV]] 1 – 0 [[AS Monaco FC|AS Monaco]] [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/europe/4281715.stm (BBC)] **[[FC Bayern Munich|Bayern Munich]] 3 – 1 [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/europe/4281683.stm (BBC)] *[[Curling]] – [[Scott Tournament of Hearts]]: The defending champion [[Colleen Jones]] rink defeats the previously undefeated [[Saskatchewan]] rink skipped by [[Stefanie Lawton]]. Jones also won her other game against [[Nova Scotia]] and sits at 4–3, while Saskatchewan drops into a tie with [[Manitoba]]'s [[Jennifer Jones (curler)|Jennifer Jones]] at 6–1. Jennifer Jones has been on a roll as well, only losing to [[British Columbia]]'s [[Kelly Scott]] in Draw 6. [http://www.cbc.ca/story/sports/national/2005/02/22/Sports/hearts050222.xhtml (CBC sports)]
===21 February 2005=== *[[Curling]] – [[Scott Tournament of Hearts]]: [[Saskatchewan]]'s [[Stefanie Lawton]] remains undefeated at 5–0 after beating [[Newfoundland and Labrador]] and [[Prince Edward Island]]. Defending champions [[Colleen Jones]] falls to [[New Brunswick]]'s [[Sandy Comeau]] but defeats [[Alberta]] and sits tied in sixth place at 2–3. [http://www.cbc.ca/story/sports/national/2005/02/21/Sports/hearts050221.xhtml (CBC sports)]
===20 February 2005=== *[[2005 NBA All-Star Game]]: The Eastern Conference All-Stars defeat the Western Conference All-Stars 125–115 [[Pepsi Center|in Denver]]. [[Philadelphia 76ers]] guard [[Allen Iverson]] is named MVP with 15 points and four steals in the game. [http://www.nba.com/games/20050220/ESTWST/recap.html (NBA)] *[[2005 in NASCAR|NASCAR]]: [[Jeff Gordon]] wins the [[Daytona 500]] from [[Kurt Busch]] and [[Dale Earnhardt, Jr.]] [http://nascar.com (NASCAR)] *[[Snooker]]: [[Ronnie O'Sullivan]] beats [[John Higgins (snooker player)|John Higgins]] 10 frames to 3 to win his second [[Masters (snooker)|Masters]] title. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/other_sports/snooker/4282449.stm (BBC)] *[[association football|Football]]: [[FA Cup]] fifth round: **[[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] 0 – 0 [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/fa_cup/4259715.stm (BBC)] **[[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] 1 – 0 [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/fa_cup/4259719.stm (BBC)] **[[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] 1 – 1 [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]] [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/fa_cup/4259713.stm (BBC)] *[[Curling]] – [[2005 Scott Tournament of Hearts]]: [[Manitoba]]'s [[Jennifer Jones (curler)|Jennifer Jones]] and [[Saskatchewan]]'s [[Stefanie Lawton]] remain the only teams to be undefeated as Jones won both of her games and Lawton her game. Both teams are 3–0. Defending champions, Team Canada skipped by [[Colleen Jones]] continues her rough start by losing to Manitoba in their morning draw but rebounding with a win over [[Newfoundland and Labrador]]'s [[Heather Strong]]. Team Canada sits at 1–2. [http://www.cbc.ca/story/sports/national/2005/02/20/Sports/hearts-sunday050220.xhtml (CBC Sports)]
===19 February 2005=== *[[association football|Football]]: [[FA Cup]] fifth round: **[[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] 1 – 1 [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] **[[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] 1 – 0 [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] **[[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]] 1 – 2 [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] **[[Everton F.C.|Everton]] 0 – 2 [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] **[[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] 2 – 2 [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]] *[[Cricket]]: [[Australia national cricket team|Australia]] (236 for 7) beat [[New Zealand national cricket team|New Zealand]] (226) by just 10 runs in the first [[One Day International]] at [[Wellington]]. *[[National Hockey League]]: Despite 6½ hours of talks between the league and [[NHL Players Association|its players union]] today, the two sides were unable to come to an agreement to end the current [[2004–05 NHL lockout|lockout]]. The [[2004–05 NHL season|current season]] remains canceled, now with no hope of resurrection. [https://sports.yahoo.com/nhl/news;_ylc=X3oDMTBpNWZic251BF9TAzI1NjY0ODI1BHNlYwN0aA--?slug=ap-nhllockout&prov=ap&type=lgns (AP/Yahoo!)] *[[Boxing]]: [[Bernard Hopkins]] makes a successful 20th defense of his middleweight title with a one-sided unanimous decision over [[Howard Eastman]] [[Staples Center|in Los Angeles]]. Hopkins becomes the first Middleweight champion in boxing history to defend that category's title twenty or more times, and joins [[Joe Louis]] and [[Abe Attell]], among few others, in the exclusive group of boxers with 20 or more title defenses in one division. [https://sports.yahoo.com/box/news;_ylc=X3oDMTBpNWZic251BF9TAzI1NjY0ODI1BHNlYwN0aA--?slug=ap-hopkins-eastman&prov=ap&type=lgns (AP/Yahoo!)][http://www.boxing-central.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=5801 (Boxing Central)] *[[Curling]]: The [[2005 Scott Tournament of Hearts]], Canada's national [[curling]] championship for women begins play at [[Mile One Stadium]] in [[St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador]]. Team Canada's [[Colleen Jones]], the defending champion is upset by [[Jenn Hanna]] of team [[Ontario]]. Elsewhere, former Scott champion [[Cathy King]] of [[Alberta]] loses both her games. [[British Columbia]]'s [[Kelly Scott]] and [[Saskatchewan]]'s [[Stefanie Lawton]] both are undefeated at 2–0 while [[Manitoba]]'s [[Jennifer Jones (curler)|Jennifer Jones]], Nova Scotia's [[Kay Zinck]], New Brunswick's [[Sandy Comeau]] in addition to Hanna are at 1–0. [http://www.cbc.ca/story/sports/national/2005/02/19/Sports/hearts-drawone050219.xhtml (CBC sports)]
===18 February 2005=== *[[American football]]: [[New England Patriots]] linebacker Tedy Bruschi suffers a stroke. *[[Ice hockey|Hockey]]: Reportedly, the [[National Hockey League]] and its players' [[labor union|union]], the [[NHL Players Association]], have reached agreement on a deal that would allow a [[2004–05 NHL season|shortened season]] to be played, despite the league's announced cancellation of the season. Reports, denied by both sides, were that a deal would be signed tomorrow. [https://sports.yahoo.com/nhl/news;_ylc=X3oDMTBpdDcyMnNwBF9TAzk1ODYxODgzBHNlYwN0bQ--?slug=ap-nhllockout&prov=ap&type=lgns (AP/Yahoo!)] Update: The sides met on 19 February, but talks failed.
===17 February 2005=== *[[Cricket]]: [[Australia national cricket team|Australia]] (214 for 5) defeat [[New Zealand national cricket team|New Zealand]] (170) by 44 runs in the first ever international [[Twenty20]] cricket match. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/cricket/4269681.stm (BBC)] *[[association football|Football]] **[[UEFA Cup]], round of 32, first leg: [http://www.uefa.com/Competitions/UefaCup/index.html (UEFA.com)] ***[[Dynamo Kyiv]] 0 – 0 [[Villarreal CF|Villarreal]] ***[[Grazer AK]] 2 – 2 [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] ***[[Fenerbahçe]] 0 – 1 [[Real Zaragoza]] ***[[FC Basel]] 0 – 0 [[Lille OSC|Lille]] ***[[Alemannia Aachen|Alemannia]] 0 – 0 [[AZ Alkmaar|AZ]] ***[[SC Heerenveen|Heerenveen]] 1 – 2 [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] ***[[PFC CSKA Moscow|CSKA Moscow]] 2 – 0 [[S.L. Benfica|Benfica]] ***[[Olympiacos CFP|Olympiacos]] 1 – 0 [[FC Sochaux-Montbéliard|Sochaux]]
===16 February 2005=== *[[association football|Football]] **[[UEFA Cup]], round of 32, first leg: [http://www.uefa.com/Competitions/UefaCup/index.html (UEFA.com)] ***[[FK Partizan|Partizan Belgrade]] 2–2 [[FC Dnipro Dnipropetrovsk|Dnipro]] ***[[FC Shakhtar Donetsk|Shakhtar Donetsk]] 1–1 [[FC Schalke 04|Schalke 04]] ***[[Ajax Amsterdam|Ajax]] 1–0 [[AJ Auxerre|Auxerre]] ***[[Panathinaikos F.C.|Panathinaikos]] 1–0 [[Sevilla FC|Sevilla]] ***[[Parma F.C.|Parma]] 0–0 [[VfB Stuttgart|Stuttgart]] ***[[Sporting Clube de Portugal|Sporting Lisbon]] 2–1 [[Feyenoord Rotterdam|Feyenoord]] ***[[Valencia CF|Valencia]] 2–0 [[FC Steaua București|Steaua Bucharest]] ***[[FK Austria Wien|Austria Vienna]]–[[Athletic Bilbao]]: postponed, snow. Rescheduled to 24 February; return leg in Bilbao scheduled for 27 February. **[[UEFA]] has announced that it will send an investigator to Greece to examine [[match fixing]] allegations surrounding a December 2004 UEFA Cup tie between [[Panionios NFC|Panionios]] and [[FC Dinamo Tbilisi|Dinamo Tbilisi]], including possible links to the ongoing [[match fixing]] scandal in Germany. ===15 February 2005=== *Cycling: [[Lance Armstrong]] announces his intentions to compete for a seventh consecutive win in the upcoming [[Tour de France]], ending speculation as to whether he would race this year or in 2006. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/other_sports/cycling/4269959.stm (BBC Sport)] *[[association football|Football]]: **In the [[Football for Hope]] [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake|tsunami]] [[Humanitarian response to the 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake|relief]] match in [[Barcelona]], a World side captained by [[Ronaldinho]] defeats a European side captained by [[Andriy Shevchenko]] 6–3. The match, although held in a more than half-empty [[Nou Camp]], raised over US$3 million. [https://www.fifa.com/en/fairplay/tsunami/index/0,4052,105373,00.html?articleid=105373 (FIFA.com)] [https://sports.yahoo.com/sow/news;_ylc=X3oDMTBpYjk0aWtjBF9TAzk1ODYzNTkwBHNlYwN0aA--?slug=ap-spain-tsunamiaid&prov=ap&type=lgns (AP/Yahoo!)] **[[Match fixing]] scandal in Germany: [https://sports.yahoo.com/sow/news;_ylc=X3oDMTBpYnF0a2UxBF9TAzk1ODYzNTkwBHNlYwN0bQ--?slug=afp-fblgercorruption&prov=afp&type=lgns (AFP/Yahoo!)] ***The [[German Football Association|German Football Association (DFB)]] has announced that one of four matches acknowledged to be [[match fixing|fixed]] by [[Robert Hoyzer]], a 22 October 2004 [[2. Bundesliga]] fixture between [[LR Ahlen|Ahlen]] and [[Wacker Burghausen]], will be replayed. ***The DFB also suspended [[referee (association football)|referee]] Dominik Marks after it was alleged that he received EUR 36,000 for fixing two matches. ***The police are set to interrogate Hoyzer about a total of 63 matches in which he was involved. **[[April Heinrichs]] resigns her position as coach of the [[United States women's national soccer team]]. [https://sports.yahoo.com/sow/news;_ylc=X3oDMTBpYjk0aWtjBF9TAzk1ODYzNTkwBHNlYwN0aA--?slug=ap-heinrichsresigns&prov=ap&type=lgns (AP/Yahoo!)] *[[Formula One]]: [[Minardi]] confirmed Austrian [[Patrick Friesacher]] as their second driver for the [[2005 Formula One season|2005 season]], to partner [[Christijan Albers]].
===14 February 2005=== *[[Hare coursing]]: **As the final Waterloo Cup event in England starts in [[Great Altcar|Altcar]], four anti-coursing protesters are arrested. The event is expected to attract up to 10,000 spectators over its 3 days. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/merseyside/4262065.stm (BBC)] [http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/in_pictures/4265251.stm (BBC)] *[[Ice hockey]]: **After last-minute talks between the [[National Hockey League]] and [[NHL Players Association|the league's players' union]] failed to resolve the [[2004–05 NHL lockout|current labor dispute]], the NHL has scheduled a press conference on 16 February, at which it is expected to call off the [[2004–05 NHL season|2004–05 season]]. [https://sports.yahoo.com/nhl/news;_ylc=X3oDMTBpbmdmam0wBF9TAzI1NjY0ODI1BHNlYwN0bQ--?slug=ap-nhllockout&prov=ap&type=lgns (AP/Yahoo!)] **The [[Boston University|Boston University Terriers]] defeat the [[Northeastern University, Boston|Northeastern Huskies]] 3–2 in [[Overtime (ice hockey)|overtime]] to win the 53rd annual [[Beanpot]] hockey tournament. [http://sports.espn.go.com/ncaa/news/story?id=1991620 (AP/ESPN)] *[[American football]]: [[Arizona]] businessman [[Reggie Fowler]] agrees to buy the [[Minnesota Vikings]] from [[Red McCombs]] for US$625 million, possibly becoming the first African-American owner of an [[National Football League|NFL]] team (subject to NFL approval).
